images.alt:
"A quiet body of water stretches across the frame, so still it behaves like polished glass. From its surface, a sparse arrangement of thin, leafless branches—or perhaps reeds—emerge like calligraphy strokes drawn by nature’s hand. Each branch is mirrored perfectly in the water below, creating symmetrical shapes that resemble abstract ink drawings or minimalist sculptures.

The background is a soft, pale blue—neither sky nor fog, but a gentle wash that erases horizon and depth. There’s no visible shore, no birds or ripples, only the delicate tension between branch and reflection. The scene feels suspended in time, as if the water is holding its breath.

In the upper right corner, a watermark reads Swede's Photographs, quietly marking the image’s origin without disturbing its serenity.

This is not a landscape—it’s a meditation. A study in restraint, balance, and the quiet drama of stillness." - Copilot

record.text: Perplexity only booked $60m in revenue in 2024, but if there was 100% uptake on this they’d be booking a billion. For having not a single (actually) paying customer. And this is just what they’re doing in Canada, a relatively small market.

Add to the list of Perplexity Pro being given away, so they can book it as full price revenue: also in Canada, to all Bell mobile and internet subscribers. Bell is a top 2 telco, for internet alone it has nearly 5 million subscribers. If you know anything about Bell, you know they wouldn’t pay.

value.text:
At this point, it's clear that it's impossible to build a profitable company around generative AI. Perpelxity spent 140% of its 2024 revenue on AWS, OpenAI and Anthropic, and winning that revenue requiired $27m in refunds. These are not good companies.  
www.wheresyoured.at/why-everybod...

images.alt:
What If It Isn't Possible To Make A Profitable AI Company?

Replit CEO Amjad Masad told The Information this week that he doesn't believe that prices for models will ever come down, and when pressed to explain how exactly it would turn a profit, he had little to say other than "uhhh, people will pay for it":

    Replit is betting it can make its coding app so convenient and easy to use that it can pass the higher costs to customers and they will endure it because they won’t need to hire as many engineers, he said. (Replit earlier this summer raised its prices for people who use its product the most.) And that will help solve Replit’s profit margin challenges, he said.

    “[O]ur bet is that enterprises will continue to want to pay a premium for a product like ours because of the convenience we bring to the organization,” he said.

Just so we're clear, his argument is that he'll charge customers more, and they'll find Replit so useful that...they'll pay more?

Replit's pricing is also odd, splitting user inputs into "simple requests" that cost a fixed 25 cents, then "complex builds" that cost "more than 25 cents but reflect the total effort involved," before saying that "transparent pricing shows you exactly what you're paying for each completed task," though not what said pricing is or how it is calculated, outside of "edit requests" that cost $0.05 each.

It seems that Replit's pricing strategy appears to be "obfuscate as much as humanely possible in the hopes users burn a lot of money," such as charging a user $350 in one day, and even then it can't seem to turn a profit. The Information reports that Replit's post-price-increase margins had increased to 23% (as of July), but these margins didn't include the cost of running AI models for its free users, which have become an expensive marketing channel for any AI Software-as-a-Service company.

This, worryingly, seems to be an industry-wide problem, outside of OpenAI.

AI boosters will argue that this is "standard accounting for software companies," in that free users are commonly left out of gross margin calculations.

While this is technically true, the burden of a free user is significantly higher for an AI company than one selling regular Software as a Service. Due to the compute-intensive nature of Large Language Models, a "free" user on Cursor — who receives a two-week-long free trial to its $20-a-month "Pro" subscription — could burn anywhere from $2 to $20 of compute without ever converting.  Though we don't know the exact economics of a ChatGPT or Claude user, I imagine it's quite easy for a free user to cost them at the very least a few cents a conversation, and not particularly hard for one to start costing them a few dollars in the space of a month.

In general, software companies are burdened by the cost of user acquisition rather than the cost of providing the service, and any service that runs on the back of Large Language Models now has to calculate for both.

Perplexity — A Doomed Company That Runs On Freebies And Venture Capital Welfare

Per The Information, Perplexity, an AI-powered search company, lost $68 million in 2024, spending 164% of its revenue ($34 million) on Amazon Web Services and models from OpenAI and Anthropic ($56 million). To be a little more specific, Perplexity made a total of $60 million in revenue, but spent $27 million on "discounts and refunds," which likely means that big partnerships like when it gave away Perplexity Pro to every Uber One subscriber are booked as revenue then refunds, which is a very, very dodgy way of running a business.

In any case, these numbers stink to high heaven.

Perplexity is apparently out in the market raising at a $20 billion valuation, months after raising $100 million at an $18 billion valuation. Because journalists do not bother following up on stories, it's unclear whether Perplexity succeeded in raising the $500 million it allegedly tried to in the middle of May, and while Crunchbase reports it as closing, I see no evidence that it has. If it did, this means that Perplexity needed more money to continue operations, so much so that on receiving one hundred million dollars it immediately said "we need more money than that."

Perplexity has no path to profitability. Even if you removed its $27 million in refunds, it would still lose $7 million dollars in 2024, and it's impossible to do that because it's very clear that Perplexity is booking the accounts it gives away as part of their partnerships as revenue. Losing money is a core part of Perplexity's DNA, and no amount of bullshitting or fake offers to buy companies changes the fact that it makes money by giving away its product at scale, a product that runs on expensive Large Language Models by design.

Perplexity is, allegedly, at $150 million in "annualized" revenue, meaning that it made $12.5 million in a calendar month, though one has to wonder how much of that revenue is from its deal to give away a year of Perplexity Pro (valued at $200) to every single Samsung Galaxy Phone or Tablet user in America. While I imagine Samsung is paying something, there are likely tens of millions of Samsung Galaxy users in America, and I imagine it’s taking a loss on every single one.

    Sidenote: Samsung is the second-largest smartphone vendor in the US, and in 2024 its share of quarterly shipments (note: not sales, but shipments into sales channels) fluctuated between 31% and 18% according to Counterpoint. While we don’t know what this translates into in terms of solid figures (in part because analyst houses often only share partial information in the hope of getting you to p…

record.bridgyOriginalText:
@futurebird I've been mentoring one of my coworkers in going and he told me about his success in learning bits of Python via Copilot. He's an en engineer not a programmer but he modified some of my test automation scripts to run production cases so I've been very supportive. I believe it's critical that the people doing the work build and own their automation and that my role is to provide inspiration, guidance, and mentoring.
When he mentioned using Copilot, I had to tamp down my initial reaction of "NOOOOOO!" and asked how it worked for him, and gave a gentle reminder that it's often unreliable and everything it produces needs to be independently checked. Ultimately, I want him to be as comfortable and in charge of his own technology as he wants to be and encourage exploration so it's both engaging and useful. He's not a programmer but he's interested and I don't want to quash that. I also want him to understand the limitations of LLMs and, if he uses one, he knows how to use it safely and responsibly.

images.alt: The Commerce Department has been suppressing Natcast’s operations for many months, IEEE Spectrum has learned. According to multiple sources, the organization’s research agenda was completed in April and should have been accepted and processed by Commerce in a matter of weeks. But it never happened. A memo selecting awardees for research into reducing the impact of perfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) from semiconductor manufacturing was submitted to Commerce but never approved. Three groups won parts of a $30 million grant to transform the design of RF chips using machine learning, but at least one awardee has gotten no word on when or whether the funding will flow.

record.text: I think one of the dilemmas about AI agents is the more private it is, the further removed it is from any kind of oversight. The less private it is, the more the user gives up personal information.
I suspect a lot of people don’t want to use a public forum to ask for advice on deeply personal matters.

Missouri Republicans were in such a rush to pass their new congressional gerrymander that they screwed up a basic part of using software to draw a valid map.

Via Mark Gaber, redistricting director at @campaignlegal.org, which just sued to block the map

images.alt: Screenshot of a tweet from Campaign Legal Center’s senior redistricting director Mark Gaber. His post compares two conflicting images of part of Missouri Republicans’ new congressional gerrymander with the text saying: “The process was so slapdash and rushed that the Legislature assigned one Kansas City precinct to TWO congressional districts. So they actually passed two maps, creating malapportioned and noncontiguous districts”

A delegation of Pakistan-Hunan Chamber of Commerce met with the minister for industries at the Punjab Small Industries Corporation (PSIC) House. The meeting focused on investment opportunities for Chinese companies in the province. Speaking on the occasion, Provincial Minister Shafay Hussain said that a cooperation and partnership agreement exists between Pakistan-Hunan Chamber and the Department of Industries and Commerce.

record.bridgyOriginalText:
设计 routine 一定要切忌贪嗔痴。如果连早上闹钟响了要不要继续睡，按下闹钟之后是憋尿刷手机，还是喝水、上厕所都还有丝毫的犹豫，那么在晨昏 routine 里面试图加入什么从来没有真的坚持过三天以上的剧烈运动、冥想瑜伽、背单词背古诗、写作之类的什么“精英日课”，就是自寻烦恼。先诚实地解决自己当前最基本的需求，让自己感觉到每天似乎没有投入什么，就获得了生活质量巨幅提升，让自己过上干净整洁、神清气爽，平静愉悦有基本尊严的生活，我的身体才会慢慢相信我的大脑不是一天天瞎指挥，才会越来越配合。

为什么早上醒来不能立刻刷手机，当然可以，但是渴了不喝水、憋着一宿的尿还要去看别人的世界在发生什么、别人给我发了什么消息，我的大脑就没有给我的身体最基本的尊重，说爱自己都是嘴上说说的。

永远有干净衣服穿、新鲜食物吃，自行车胎永远有气，床单整洁舒适、房间窗明几净，头发每天干爽，出门电量满格，文件夹、桌面、邮箱、笔记软件条理清晰，知道今天天气。做我的心上人，至少应该是这种体验。

external.description: The episode discusses the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission's (SEC) approval of spot XRP Exchange-Traded Funds (ETFs) in October 2025, a decision that is expected to significantly impact the digital asset market. This approval, following a 2024 reclassification of XRP as a commodity, opens doors for both retail and institutional investors to access XRP through regulated financial instruments, potentially driving substantial price appreciation and market liquidity. The text explores the journey to approval, the implications for investors, and projected market impacts, including various price predictions and potential risks. It also highlights Ripple's strategic initiatives and the broader trend of institutional adoption within the cryptocurrency landscape, emphasizing the transformative role of XRP ETFs in the future of finance.

record.text: 📣 New Podcast! "What is love ❤ in a relationship?" on @Spreaker #lovepodcast #marriages #relationships #romancepodcast

external.description: The episode explores the complex nature of love within romantic relationships, framing it as both a profound emotion and a conscious choice. It outlines foundational components like intimacy, passion, and commitment, drawing on theories such as Sternberg's Triangular Theory of Love. The article emphasizes the crucial roles of effective communication, trust, and vulnerability in fostering connection and mutual growth. Additionally, it examines how love is influenced by cultural contexts and evolves over time, while also acknowledging challenges and the importance of self-love and understanding different "love languages" for sustained fulfillment.
external.title: What is love ❤ in a relationship?

早朝の #Grok 遊び

人口ピラミッドを視野に入れて、選挙動静分析は年代ではなく「世代」で分析するべきじゃね？　論をぶち上げる。
高齢層をただ60〜70代とか70〜80代と見ずに「第一次ベビーブーム世代」「第二次ベビーブーム世代」と分割して投票分析した方が【動き】が見えるんじゃないか的な。
別に歳食ったら自民支持になる訳でもないからなぁ。

キュピン！

あ、これアムロが居ない【逆シャア】なんじゃね？

youtu.be/94o5QYqgxo0?...

そらーまー「メビウスの輪から抜け出せません」わー
毎年夏の終わりに自民党総裁選やる羽目になるやで。

政治家を官僚が実効支配するやり方って民主主義とは相容れないやり方だからねぇ。官僚は国民の審判受けないから、国民主権を重視するならポピュリズムで選出された代議士に「従って貰わねば困る」
それが嫌なら民主主義やめなきゃならんもんなぁ。

てか、今あれか、民主主義をナチュラルに構造改革して「官僚支配体制に移行中」だわな。
自由民主党が民主主義に背を向けたんじゃなぁ。
